abstract.text: A standard view controller, whose interface lets the user manage, edit, and send email messages.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Use this view controller to display a standard email interface inside your app. Before presenting the interface, populate the fields with initial values for the subject, email recipients, body text, and attachments of the email. After presenting the interface, the person can edit your initial values before sending the email.

The composition interface doesn’t guarantee the delivery of your email message; it only lets you construct the initial message and present it for user approval. The person may opt to cancel the composition interface which discards the message and its contents. If the person opts to send the message, the message queues in the user’s Mail app outbox. The Mail app is ultimately responsible for sending the message.
You must not modify the view hierarchy presented by this view controller. However, you can customize the appearance of the interface using the
An alternate way to compose emails is to create and open a URL that uses the
scheme. URLs of that type go directly to the built-in Mail app, which uses your URL to configure a message. For information about the structure of

content.text: Checking the availability of the composition interface

inlineContent.text: Before presenting the mail compose view controller, always call the

method to see if the person configured the current device to send email. If the person’s device isn’t set up for the delivery of email, you can notify the person or disable the email dispatch features in your application. You shouldn’t attempt to use this interface if the

content.text: Configuring and displaying the composition interface

inlineContent.text: After verifying that mail services are available, you can create and configure the mail composition view controller and then present it as any other view controller. Use the methods of this class to specify the subject, recipients, and message body of the email, including any attachments you want to send with the message. The sample code below shows how to configure the composition interface and present it modally. Always assign a delegate to the
property, because the delegate is responsible for dismissing the composition interface later.

code: // Configure the fields of the interface.
// Configure the fields of the interface.

inlineContent.text: After presenting a mail compose view controller, the system ignores any attempts to modify the email using the methods of this class. The user can still edit the content of the email, but your app can’t. Therefore, always configure the fields of your email
The mail compose view controller isn’t dismissed automatically. When the user taps the buttons to send the email or cancel the interface, the mail compose view controller calls the

method of its delegate. Your implementation of that method must dismiss the view controller explicitly, as shown in sample code below. You can also use this method to check the result of the operation.

code: // Check the result or perform other tasks.
// Dismiss the mail compose view controller.
// Check the result or perform other tasks.
// Dismiss the mail compose view controller.

inlineContent.text: The user can delete a queued message before it’s sent. Although the view controller reports the success or failure of the operation to its delegate, this class doesn’t provide a way for you to verify if the email sent.
For more information on how to present and dismiss view controllers, see

Create a user interface for composing email and text messages, so users can edit and send messages without leaving your app.

objects that are associated with the mail composition interface.
The domain used for error objects that are associated with the mail composition interface.
A standard view controller, whose interface lets the user manage, edit, and send email messages.
Adds the specified data as an attachment to the message.
Returns a Boolean that indicates whether the current device is able to send email.
The mail composition view controller’s delegate.
Sets the initial recipients to include in the email’s Bcc field.
Sets the initial recipients to include in the email’s Cc field.
Sets the initial body text to include in the email.
Sets the preferred email address to use in the From field, if such an address is available.
Sets the initial text for the subject line of the email.
Sets the initial recipients to include in the email’s To field.
An interface for responding to user interactions with a mail compose view controller.
Tells the delegate that the user wants to dismiss the mail composition view.
A container view controller that defines a stack-based scheme for navigating hierarchical content.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for adapting the contents of your view controllers to size and trait changes.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
Methods for adding objects to your state restoration archives.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
